review_title: Good research, but poor pay with too many hidden fees
pros: Top research institute, with a large variety of research opportunities and leading experts. Research opportunities range from access to the National High Magnetic Field Lab, to a strong astrophysics department, and even an underground particle accelerator.
cons: Grad stipend close to minimum wage in the state, and offered stipend doesn't reflect the actual income due to many hidden fees. These fees are part of a "pay to work" scheme, where one's stipend is predicated on them being able to pay fees. Fees can range up to 9k a year for domestic (and higher for international) students. Too much bureaucratic burden for underpaid grad students, with extra fees (on top of those mentioned above) for forgetting some trivial paperwork. Also, no guarantee that one will be paid on time. While rare, if some human error occurs up the bureaucratic chain, one might be left for a month without income, while additionally being required to still pay fees. Failure to pay fees means you will not get income. It is an unnecessary vicious cycle. Generally a great research institute, and my department was fantastic, but the university policies are predatory.

review_title: School refuses to pay graduate students appropriate stipen

I actually did the math, and I would make more money working only 40 hrs/week at most McDonalds. Additionally, school is refusing to give adequate raise in light of inflation (FSU is fighting the grad student union over a 1% raise when inflation is 6% - a raise of anything less than 6% is a paycut.) Tallahassee is not cheap to live in - rent has gone up significantly this year (Can't find a 1 bedroom apartment for less than $1000/month, and housing with roommates near the university is also expensive (avg $600-800/month)).

review_title: If you get the chance, work for Club Downunder/ Union Productions!!
job_title: Director of Marketing and Public Relations in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
Working for the events organization on campus exposed me to a lot of things that I wouldn't have experienced otherwise. Part of the job is attending the events and maintaining coverage of what Union Productions is up to, and that aspect is a lot of fun.
Also, the team that I worked with during my time at Union Productions was incredibly creative, driven, and kind. Collaborating with such individuals is a privilege and an honor. 
As a student, you will have a lot of freedom to create interesting campaigns and undertake projects that interest you. There are a lot of different ways to involve yourself and grow your skills, and the senior exec members are very helpful when it comes to training people who are interested in video production, audio production, graphic design, event planning, podcast production, publications, and more. It's a learning environment and the professional development that you can gain here is unmatched if you commit yourself and just reach out to others for help.
cons: I mean, from the perspective of Union Productions, the bureaucracy of the university can be frustrating at times. Pacing your projects to match upcoming events can be difficult to achieve due to the unpredictability of live events combined with the needed cooperation of multiple departments of the university. Working at Union Productions definitely teaches you to be patient with yourself and others while challenging you to be flexible and think on the go. However, I would say that the skills learned from the cons of working at Union Productions outweigh the cons themselves and will serve you well as you go on to other jobs in the future.

pros: Very flexible scheduling. Night Staff uses schedulefly- an online scheduling system used for resturants- to schedule shifts. You can exchange shifts whenever, and if you don't feel like working, you can put your shift up (someone needs to take it though). Pretty easy to get shifts covered, and the coordinators take consideration of tests and if you aren't feeling well. After all, it is an overnight job. Hours suck (10:30p-7:30a) but you get used to it and are usually home by 7:30 because they cut you loose at 7. Pretty much all of the job is just sitting at the desk, with the exception being the occasional emergency, so it is a good job to knock out a bunch of homework, projects, or even get some studying done. I've also gotten a 35 cent pay raise since I started just by being around for so long.
cons: Like I said, the hours. 9 hour overnight shifts can be a bit rough, and it shows in the high turnover.  Sometimes you have to deal with some crappy incidents, but if you work the right nights (not weekends), you'll very rarely deal with this sort of stuff. It is also a job that, for the most part, you will be alone. If that's you, cool, but sometimes it does get a bit lonely and a lot of the staff can be a bit socially awkward anyways. Sometimes the programming/meetings can be a bit pointless.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Decent weather compared to most states. Robust facilities like gym, tennis courts, swimming pool, running tracks, libraries etc. Office of Postdoc Affairs is a strong advocate of postdocs but has limited say.
cons: The sad state and mismanagement of postdocs in the United States is well documented in many places. Please read about it carefully before committing to it. If you still feel this is the best way forward, then FSU is one of the better places to work. That said, there is no uniformity in the paychecks of postdoc - even within the same department. Faculty are strongly opposed to the idea of higher pay to postdocs due to their own issues with raising grant money. It was a monumental effort to get them to pay for postdoc insurance. Life for international postdocs is vastly more difficult since FSU will not offer support to file for residency. Given that only 10% of postdocs get faculty positions, the remaining 90% will need to search for positions elsewhere and that search becomes astronomically more difficult for international scholars.

review_title: If you're looking for a great education, you can certainly find it here.
pros: Large University with many academic/administrative departments and organizations; work-study opportunities available for qualifying students; University scholarships automatically awarded to students with high-academic achievements; abundant scholarships/student project funding available to students upon application.  Whether living on or off campus, embraced in "college" atmosphere and experience.  Work/study/life balance manageable; tuition extremely affordable (Florida Bright Futures program qualifies almost all residents 50-100% tuition discount).  Large, but contained campus with stunning brick landscape.  Vast selection of coursework and extra-curricular opportunities available for every student.  Infectious school spirit!
cons: Large university can be overwhelming; easy to get lost in large student body.  More specifically, only basic academic advising/related services provided for general student body (lack individual attention available at smaller institution).  The advising departments for individual majors (especially larger majors--e.g. Biology, English) exhibit very low level of inter-departmental communication; student must be own resource/department liaison.  Many amazing professors willing to mentor individual students; however, generally must excel academically or otherwise to form relationship with professor (and FSU student body is a very large crowd to stand out from).

review_title: Challenging work, but the freedom to study and discover something new and that interests you in rewarding.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
This depends on your advisor, but the freedom to choose your schedule is great, although you are working constantly including many times during holidays. Also, schedule can be informal, so if you decide to take a week off from work or a three day vacation here or there (Friday+weekend or weekend+Monday), it's okay as long as you get your work done. Was often able to work off campus at coffee shops or at home as well.

Finally, it's rewarding to be able to study what you want and make discoveries in a field that interests you. It keeps you engaged and invigorated. I think it's such a privilege to be able to do that.
cons: Sometimes your advisor can be be a jerk or not give good advice which can make you aimless and preventing you from graduating on time. Also, this doesn't have to do with the job, but traveling out of Tallahassee is a pain. Flights are expensive and infrequent. It can be an all day affair just to travel up the eastern seaboard let alone other more distant parts of the country. Tallahassee is also pretty isolated, so driving to Atlanta (4.5-5 hrs), Orlando/Tampa (4-5 hours), or Miami (8-9 hours) can be a total pain.

pros: I am not a Florida State graduate, however that never mattered. The Office makes you feel like you are a part of the family, the community, and makes you proud to represent the University. It is a fast paced, high intense, environment, but they are supportive and understanding. One huge pro is that the Office is in the exterior of the stadium, so parking  is easy and you won't get stuck in the normal campus traffic. It's also nice because when you need to take a stress break you can walk around inside the stadium which is generally 15 degrees cooler than the exterior.
cons: It's an admissions office for one of the larger and high profile universities in the country. With this comes a high volume of applications and a lot of conversation regarding things outside of the Office. If an athlete gets in trouble or the University makes an unpopular decision, you will have to address it for a few days. However, the Office is great about providing the best way to address these matters.

review_title: A lot of resources, but the pay is rather marginal.
pros: At least in my department (College of Communication) they do a good job of making sure that teaching assistants are trained well to handle the load that's placed upon them, and they're willing to communicate with you and help you. They've tried to make things easier on TAs recently by cutting teaching loads somewhat as well.
cons: My pay is okay here, but it barely covers rent, and that's assuming you stay in an apartment that's at the low end of the spectrum. This may be a factor of my assistantship only being .25 FTE (I know many other people do 0.5 FTE), but I know other institutions pay their TAs/GAs a lot more since I have a lot of friends at other places. But even with the cuts they've made to the teaching loads, its still a lot and it still takes up a lot of time.

pros: Good colleagues, a good provost, mostly good students (and a few who are extremely good), low cost of living area. Clear, challenging, but reasonable expectations for tenure.  Nice old trees in some parts of town.
cons: Football culture, ugh. Sleazy politicians at the top harming the many decent lower-level folks.  A good provost, but variable deans, very variable chairs, and a criminally underfunded library. Very worrisome future horizons.  Assessment wonk, a young and hyper-ambitious ed-school type, changed our good curriculum to an experimental nightmare.  Far too much committee work and busy-service-work, but that varies by department. As a place to live, Tallahassee is difficult at best. "Cheap" is about the only good thing I can say.  Two good restaurants in town. No real culture. Extreme heat and humidity most of the year; brief respite in January and February only. Every smart colleague I know is on the market; this is a chance for some big universities to cherry-pick some under-appreciated talent.

pros: Meeting different people from around Florida
cons: Everything from building managers to building 2

review_title: Great mentors, but lacking competitive stipend
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The work climate is very pleasant and harmonious and the administration takes both the mental and physical health of the students seriously.
cons: We have to pay graduate tuition fees out of our already less than competitive stipends. We have to pay a subsidized portion of our health insurance ourselves. Compared to other universities, this puts us at a disadvantage - sending a lot of us barreling below the poverty line. Many of us graduate with further debt because we are forced to pay for emergencies with credit cards or take out student loans.

pros: If you are looking for an Ops gig at FSU then you should definitely check out SAFE. You need to be a good driver, and the hours are a little tough at first (7pm - 2:30am), but the job is all fun and games for the most part. Just be damn sure that you're (1) responsible, (2) A GOOD DRIVER, and (3) have decent people skills and you'll be just fine. None of you "wild as hell" stop-sign/red light running texting while driving maniacs need to apply. You will be driving a van full of people and you are responsible for them. On slow nights you'll even have some time to get some homework done.
cons: As a supervisor it was a real pain dealing with people not showing up, lying, whining about schedules and breaks, writeups... I didn't take any of their crap though; that's what makes you a boss.

pros: Jobs offer a great benefits package as well as the option to pursue a graduate degree for free while receiving all benefits that students do (use of gym, parking, football tickets, etc). Salary leaves a bit to be desired, as do most public sector jobs, but many offices are understanding that younger graduates use the jobs for experience and a stepping stone. Many offices willing to help employees reach their goals
cons: Only 2 real cons, which are salary and job ceiling. Being a public sector job, it is harder to get to get regular or substantial raises within the University. Many offices also have a ceiling that is difficult to get past and to advance your career it is often required to change offices or leave entirely.

review_title: I learned a lot, but still left to be desired.
pros:
You're going to learn a LOT and have the opportunity to develop skills that employers will be looking for when you graduate. 

Depending on where you are assigned and who you are assigned with, you will have a great team to work with and gain lasting relationships and a great opportunity to create/grow your network.

While arguable, benefits and pay are better than most student jobs in the University.
cons:
At the same time, depending on where you are assigned and who you are assigned with, you could have a team where you could struggle to get along with your coworkers, your residents, or even both. 

Depending on where you are assigned, you might be busy enough where you have to give up your extracurricular activities, clubs, and other non-academic priorities.

University Housing's policies are plentiful and strict. This is not a position where you can make the position as your own. You have to adhere to their standards to the letter.

review_title: For the most part, the Foundation is a great place to work.
pros:
Excellent benefits package (generous retirement and vacation policies, especially). 

Very nice facility to work in with most employees having their own office.

Feel good about the work we do in that it enhances educational opportunities for students at the university.
cons:
No clear career path for advancing in the organization. Someone has to leave for you to get a promotion, though it seemed upper management found ways to promote the people they liked best (regardless of job performance).

Location is somewhat incovenient to get to.

Often feel like your ideas and opinions are not listened to by upper management. Everyone just seems interested in keeping their job.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Bessemer City, NC
pros: A lot of the pros and cons at FSU depend on which department you work in, who you are with, and so on. But in terms of university-wide benefits, I found the stipend reasonable, and the health care excellent. Conditions improved dramatically after Graduate Assistants United gained collective bargaining rights.
cons:
Because Florida is a right-to-work state, the GA union was struggling for support while I was there. Relationship between GA's and the University was generally good, but sometimes FSU did not share information to which the union was entitled.

Another disadvantage depends on your department, but it seemed common: Like all too many universities, work-life balance is not given as high a priority as it should be in many cases.

pros: On the right team, FSU is a comfortable place to work. The benefits include tuition waivers, excellent healthcare, generous leave policy among other things. The campus is beautiful, and it's rewarding to know you're helping educate the next generation.
cons: There is almost no opportunity for advancement for staff unless you "know" someone. Managers receive very little support from the higher-ups, so lower-ranked employees take advantage/abuse the system. Supervisors are not permitted to discipline their direct reports (any infractions get sent to HR, where they may or may not take any action weeks later.) Staff in general are not recognized or appreciated. As many others have mentioned, the pay is not commiserate with the work.

pros: The Florida State Visitors Center puts the aspect of being a student first. Scheduling is made to be flexible with your class schedules and time for studying. The environment is professional for a college student and supervisors are very approachable for any situation, professional or personal. It is the greatest thing to officially represent the university and talk to visitors and prospective students about Florida State.
cons: The biggest challenge is conducting tours on those hot summer days ... but you get used to it.

pros: ACE Learning Studio is adept at catering to each student and focusing on transforming their weaknesses into strengths. ACE offers an array of subjects, as well as standardized test prep, and has been proficient in its industry for many years. All courses are taught by various tutors which drives ACE to the top because each tutor brings something different to the work culture, and as a result, has the chance to learn new knowledge each day and expand upon their subject.
cons: ACE falls slightly behind in promoting its awareness around campus. Even though it is recognized by a fair amount of students each semester, more students should be taking advantage of ACE because the tutors are highly trained, experienced individuals and all tutoring is offered at no cost.

pros: Contrary to what some may think, working at a university has several benefits. For one, employee tuition waivers are amazing and let you continue your education for free. Another great benefit is the health insurance options, which are in line with the state. Also, the paid time off per year is really hard to compete with, especially for the private sector. The atmosphere is also pretty relaxed and goal driven. You are constantly surrounded be well educated people.
cons: Parking is one serious negative. Another is the drama that comes with dealing with students and parents. The third and most annoying is dealing with the people who think you owe them something; because, your salary comes from tax dollars.

job_title: Student Recruiter, International Programs in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Florida State University is truly the best university to be a student and to work for. They focus on educating the whole individual in both an academic stance as well as culturally. The office of International Programs changed my life through studying abroad so having a job where I got to share this experience with other students and helping to answer questions about studying abroad could not have been a more positive experience. International programs helps their recruiters with professional development, and presentation skills coaching. The team at International Programs is truly like a family, just as the whole Florida State University community. Best place to work! And Tallahassee is a wonderful place to live!
cons: The pay is not high, but better than other jobs paid to students. I truly have nothing bad to say about the working environment or culture of this office.

review_title: A good experience when you are a graduate student
pros: As a graduate student, you can get paid as a teaching assistant (TA), research assistant (RA), a consultant, or a grader.  Depending on what you want to do, funding and availability, you can choose how much you want to work besides your classes.
cons: If you are a TA be prepared to deal with some rude undergrads at times.  Also, there is little to zero funding for the summer semesters so be prepared to find a job during the summer so that you can keep paying rent.  If you are an international student you should have savings or work with some professors that have grants because after your 1 summer there is virtually no chance of ever teaching during the summer.  Also Tallahassee is horrible specially if you have allergies.

review_title: Double think before you choose to come Florida State University for work. I have worked as a graduate research assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Most of the staff there are very nice, efficient. They have very good gym and library. The environment is nice but too sunny in summer.
cons: The place Tallahassee is kind of isolated from other main cities. If you are self-motivated, it's Okay. But generally if you work as a researcher, you will feel you don't many colleagues to discuss problems. The reason is FSU is the only big university in this area.

review_title: Fun Environment, Good Benefits, Youthful Atmosphere
pros: Being that it is a university, there is a generally youthful feel to the work environment. People are professional, but they are not stuffy. Everybody is generally amicable. My management has been very flexible with time-off requests and are generally understanding. I feel like a valuable employee here.
cons: Being that it is government work, the pay is not as high as it is in the private sector. This is especially true in times of state and federal budget cuts. University leadership is aware of this and does what they can to help, but unfortunately they cannot do much.

pros: Great environment. Wonderful people. Intellectually stimulating.  Top tier research university.  University respects what post-docs bring to the research and learning environment.  I would recommend to anyone seeking a wonderful experience post-graduate school.
cons: There really isn't much I didn't appreciate about working at Florida State University.  Anyone can gripe about pay or benefits, but I felt both were appropriate for a post-doc position.  Politics may get tiresome but that will be the case at any university or organization, and it's all in how you play it.

review_title: Graduate Student and Researcher at Engineering Campus
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
- Low stress learning environment
- The faculty tends to be extremely helpful and knowledgeable, though the limited number of faculty results in areas with lower degrees of specialization
cons:
- Politics at engineering school from FAMU/FSU association can complicate matters
- Due to being a smaller program, it does not have the resources (for students or researchers) that may be available at a larger school

review_title: Enhancement of my theoretical basis of Chemistry through application in a stimulating setting, yet rewarding employment.
pros:
~The ability to experience the laboratory from an employee perspective as opposed to a student
~Friendly, warm environment
~Learned important instrument calibration, hazardous waste transportation,  equipment management, preparation of chemical inventory, interpersonal communication, and experimental design 
~Felt as if paid to have fun 
~Flexible schedules
cons:
~Prolonged renovation and repair of the lab resulted in many failed experiments due to sensitive fire alarms
~Students never follow protocol, which leads to more broken glassware to clean
~Exposure to harmful substances and situations raised anxiety
~Cleaning an entire eight-room floor of the laboratory

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
If you are a graduate student and an RA, the university pays off your tuition fee
You will have access to latest technologies and you are given freedom of thought to serve the Research community well
cons: I cannot think of many cons. However, I thought there should be someway to protect and help students in the case they lost their job and they have a situation of paying fee for next semester. It sounds silly but, as an international student the tuition fee is higher than residents(3 times more) and it comes a shock to us if there is no help from the University.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Florida State University, FL
pros: You get paid when they say you will (most of the time).
cons: The management is extremely uncooperative, and they are constantly trying to get more and more work out of you, even though you are most likely a full time student as well.  This job was fun for the first year, but over the past two years the management and new policies being put in place have truly ruined the atmosphere.  So many people have quit that they have been forced to exhaust their "alternate" list of RAs for the past two years straight.

review_title: I was honored to have been given the opportunity to be an adjunct instructor.
pros: I enjoyed the opportunity to offer professional experience and input along with the valuable content delivered in teaching typography to graphic design students.  The department personnel were welcoming and very helpful with all my dealings.  The experience was very useful and I learned a lot about academia and the college experience currently.
cons: Some aspects of the process which seemed very automatic to those in the department were not in place and the initial setup of logins, email accounts and communications took effort to get in place.  It all worked out fine, however.

review_title: Great place to pursue a graduate degree (Physics)
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The physics department at FSU is very supportive and wants all of their students to do well. It is not an academically competitive culture with students vying to be top of the class, instead collaboration is encouraged and almost necessary to succeed in classes. There is a wide variety of research opportunities for physics students with a linear accelerator on campus, the National High Magnetic Field Lab a few miles away, a high energy group with strong ties to CERN, and a lot more.
cons: The controversial new hiring of FSUs president puts the schools future ranking trajectory in question. While the Stipend is sufficient for the cost of living in Tallahassee, tuition fees take a substantial chunk.

pros: Everyone I interacted with in the College of Business were extremely nice and helpful. As a student employee my supervisor was considerate and respectful. My supervisor understood that I was a student first, and would often let me pull out my textbooks and study when the office was slow.
cons: It could be difficult to find a work study job in a department that interests and engages you. I was lucky enough to find a position in the College of Business were I am currently a student at and enjoy.

review_title: Easy job, but could be unorganized
job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The job was very easy. I could do homework or watch Netflix. I got to know a lot of the residents and they would even bring me food and things sometimes. My original supervisor when I was hired was really good at her job. I became friends with my coworkers.
cons: Sometimes it was unclear what was expected of you, it could be a bit disorganized. You were expected to work holidays even when most the students weren't even there. The pay was just minimum wage with no room for growth.

review_title: Pay is extremely low for amount of work they expect from you.
pros: The pros are you get free tuition with working with the university, some departments allow you to make up time by staying late or coming in early. The rating system is rather fair.
cons: For advancement you have to apply for your promotion. If the job titles are remotely similar they won't give you a raise. They pay staff very low wages. They pay the lowest overall wages to staff compared to all other State Universities in Florida. They do provide training classes that are not helpful unless you already know how to do something and just need further guidance. Human resources is very biased and normally sides with upper management.

review_title: Great experience, laid-back atmosphere, when you take initiative and take on projects, rewards are exponential.
job_title: Coordinator of Student Assistants in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
As a student, I had the opportunity to have a very flexible work schedule.  
as long as I completed my daily tasks, I have the chance to work on personal projects that would improve the efficiency of the office.
cons: Some coworkers do not complete their fair share of the work.  That behavior isn't always admonished, and other workers must pick up the load.

job_title: Teaching Faculty I in Tallahassee, FL
pros: It is a job. There are few things to enjoy about it.
cons:
Starting salary is the lowest in Florida with little upward mobility. Additional job requirements can be added at anytime with no additional pay increase. 

Despite being fiscally dependent upon the tuition of the large student body in the liberal arts courses, the research faculty is treated like gods over the mere mortal teachers, making double and triple salaries. For example, a teaching faculty member is lucky to be given a $500 merit raise, while a tenure faculty member can receive a $5,000 discretionary increase in salary on top of a larger merit raise. 

In short, FSU perpetuates the wealth inequality gap without shame for its immoral practices. 

I would avoid this job at all costs.

job_title: Online Course Developer in Tallahassee, FL
pros: FSU is the place where you serve the students and faculty with your passion. The work environment is decent and friendly. However, it really depends on what school you are in. If you work at FSU, you work for the state. The benefits are really tempting. You have opportunities to take on-the-job training classes for individual development.
cons: Some of the academic programs really needs to be optimized. That is to say, from the professors to the staff, updated changes need to be made. The school is well-known for college football, but the academic reputations have long way to go.

pros: You meet lots of people, the staff is nice, its hourly. Its a pretty good part time job, you call if you want to work or they'll call you.. During football season is the best time to join in. The interviews are really easy, and after you get the job you fill out some paper work and then have to come in for a test that has like 10 questions on it from the powerpoint they show you before. Good luck!
cons: They don't answer the phones if its not a dang Monday or Tuesday, and some of the people who come there don't like the rules so they get little funky attitudes, and its bi-weekly.

review_title: It's an OK place to work.
pros: At FSU, you are around some very interesting and intelligent coworkers.  Mostly, it's a relaxed atmosphere.  The students coming and going mean that there are always new and interesting people to know.  The institution has reasonable computer network support, and benefits similar to other government positions.
cons: Salaries below the commercial sector.  There is very limited chance for advancement unless you are an academic.  There are multiple examples of senior employees who have very limited real-world experience.  Salaries are currently frozen a the university.  The University has very limited capabilities for working from home.  There is no accessible VPN.  Parking is a nightmare.

review_title: It's hard to get a job on-Campus  as a n International Student.
job_title: Processess Coordinator At the Art Center in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Coworkers are extremely helpful and friendly , the facilities are very well equipped and the overall atmosphere is quite neat.
cons: The first challenge I ran into was finding someone who would hire an international student, I reckon it should not be that hard being that as international students our only job opportunity is on-campus, instead of having priority we are told to wait in the system but rarely we get a call back.

review_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Biological Science Department
pros: Professors in the Department are very knowledgable in their respective fields and accessible.  This creates a very collegiate communal environment.  Postdocs and other Assistant researchers in the Biological Sciences Department can feel comfortable with approaching a wide range of professors for advice and insight.
cons: In general, FSU is still in the process of creating a Postdoc support system. So, some of the benefits present at other Universities or Research Institutions are still being assessed for possible implementation. Although, they did recently expand employer health insurance benefits to Postdocs.

review_title: Not a horrible place to work.
pros: Free professional development. Chance to work on various committees. They do do a pretty good job of recognizing the hard work and efforts of their employees with service awards and the like.
cons: Parking is horrible! Also, you can be stretched thin if you don't watch out. I was serving on 5 committees at on time in addition to my regular duties. That meant more time was being spent working on these sub-projects and not my day to day job. My work did suffer for it and I had to eventually let my supervisor know that I could not serve on so many committees.

review_title: FSU is a community and family
job_title: Senior Assistant Director in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Working at FSU means you automatically join a "work family" and a community of professionals who value one another.  The campus is beautiful and buzzing with energy from students and staff.  Every day is different and most days my job is very rewarding because of the success of our students.
cons: Many staff are underpaid and expected to produce a high quality of work often above job responsibilities which can lead to stress and high turn-over.  Parking is terrible.

pros: I enjoyed working with the very intelligent students at FSU. Teaching is demanding but fulfilling work. I also enjoyed having health insurance.
cons: Most professors are overworked and stretched too thin. I found it difficult at times to receive the kind of support that would significantly help me grow professionally. Graduate students could also benefit from instruction on how to seek employment outside of academia as professorial positions are few and far between.

review_title: It was a nice place to work
pros: It was a nice place to work and the management was very organized and it was a well run organization. Everyone was asked to do stuff, but my coworkers were really good about doing there job so I'd never have to pick up the slack. You get to watch the football games from the sideline if you're working the event. Really flexible scheduling.
cons: Some days were really hot, running around working outdoors in the Florida sun. You'd have to set up and break down events so some times you'd have to sign up for long shifts if you want to work the event.

review_title: GOOD IF YOU KNOW THE RIGHT PEOPLE
pros: you get a lot of freedom, which is really nice.  I like the people, but with everything there is a lot politics.  So, just play the game and you will be fine.
cons: we had really small offices didnt get a rise in the pst threeyears and there are no raieses expected in teh immediate futhers. it really was tragic.  Plus new hires are hired on at significantly higher rates than existing peope

review_title: Great experience, Needs to be #1 priority
pros:
Diverse staff
Opportunity to form relationships from coworkers to residents
Cheaper housing
1/2 off housing fees, $300 flexbucks a semester, and you get paid minimum wage for a 20 hour work week- Was great for the extra cash flow but I decided it wasn't worth the stress because I didn't need the money
Great resume builder
cons:
Have to be back in room every night by 2 am weekdays and 4 am weekends
Sometimes holidays depending on building assignment
Living where you work, so sometimes residents would knock on my door at 3 in the morning and I would have to deal with the issue

review_title: Not the best place to start your career
pros: Quickly gaining national popularity, so it helps to have your name associated with FSU. Football, if that is your thing.
cons: HR bases their salary on information from what must be 20 years ago. If you work in Student Services, prepare to be low-paid compared to your colleagues nationwide. Tallahassee is not a "cheap" place to live, but based on the pay you would think otherwise. No one with a Bachelor's degree should have to live on 25,000 a year.

pros: Extremely flexible schedule. My supervisors all know that I am a student so they understand my needs and always work with me when creating my own schedule. It is convenient to work and go to school all in the same place. My experience also helped me have applicable experience to positions later on.
cons: I honestly can't think of any. My position is so flexible and I am good at what I do. This position is the perfect job for a student.

review_title: Operations Assistant at Assessment and Testing
pros: This a great environment that promotes furthering ones education and most departments will allow you work and take classes. I worked at the Testing Center where I started at part-time and moved to full-time. Overall a flexible, but busy work environment.
cons: If you are unable to deal with students then this is not the right place for you. You will be dealing with undergrads and grad students all the time and will have to constantly explain the rules and regulations of the testing center. There is not much room for growth within this part of the organization.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Price, location, School is famous for being National Champions. There are many opportunities for funding as well, either at the graduate or undergraduate level. There are a lot of resources available to students. There are also a lot of networking opportunities
cons: There is a problem with communication, especially at such a big school. You have to look for and be aware of on your own. The school is very supportive of the football team which is bad only because a lot of things on campus revolve around the football schedule so the library will be closed on game days

review_title: Night Staff is a fantastic job for night owls
pros:
First, you get paid around 8.50, which is higher than minimum wage in florida.

There's a lot of down time in a shift. You do 5 set of rounds throughout the evening and log stuff. Not much heavy duty work there. The rigor of your work depends on when and where you are stationed for the night. You'll find a lot less work in McCollum on a Tuesday than Wildwood on a Saturday.

The student supervisors and head staff are wonderful. The supervisors are extremely warm, kind, and knowledgable. They're your backup if things get too crazy for you and they will follow through. Head Staff is great as well. They are very prompt in return calls and emails and will follow up with you to ensure everything is well.

You meet many new people. I've made friends with many RAs and even some residents who are up as well. The resident life in the halls you supervise will make or break your experience as night staff.

This is a customer service position so you'll pick up a lot of face time with residents, guest, cops, parents, administrators, etc. This job will definitely test your confrontational skills.
cons:
Nine hours shift will burn you out after a while. 10:30pm-7:30am. It best to make sure you get some sleep before work or you'll have a bad time. Resetting yourself is pretty difficult.

Although supervisors are really friendly, some won't go on their set of rounds to each of the halls. 

Things get lonely at 3 and 4 in the morning, and you still have a few hours to go.

There's just night staff, then supervisor. No other promotion opportunities.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
In addition to a robust graduate physics curriculum, most offered experimental research opportunities allow one to further develop his/her programming experience, often using large-data sets.

In terms of programming languages and scripting, most groups will likely utilize C / C++ and maybe Python if really preferred (depends upon how many of the groups programs are already in C++ and whether you can demonstrate ability to use your time efficiently to do your work with Python instead; if desired).

In Particle Physics or Hadronic Nuclear Physics, one will likely use ROOT (akin to MATLAB but free and widely used by particle physics community).  In Condensed Matter, one may more likely use MATLAB and perhaps even R.

In Theoretical Physics (phenomenological/computational Physics) and Theoretical Astro-Nuclear Physics, you'll likely be using FORTRAN.  Yet in Astrophysics or Theoretical Nuclear, you likely will use C++ and Python.

In terms of transitioning to industry ought academia not work out, you will transition to software engineer / data scientist / quantitative analyst.  From left to right, you'll need experience using C/C++, Python, Java, R.  As an optimization analyst, you need simply VBA, Access, and Excel.
cons: Large school.  Trust yourself and instincts when trying to get into a group.  Many professors at large schools will not take value in you as your highschool guidance counselor would.  It is a business, and you could be dropped from a group in the middle (even after 3 years) unless you have gotten your committee form signed (get it signed!)  Don't fall for the carrot at the end of the stick routine.  Professors are notorious for moving the ball over and over down the field in terms of timeline towards graduation.  You need to get over your dream group quickly and get with a group that will value you early so you can do well over the course of 5 to 5.5 or 6 years.

review_title: Great place to work and grow your skill set!
pros: Great place to work in a relaxed environment with flexibility to grow and work on projects with technologies you are interested in learning. There are also chances for publications in research journals with the work completed during the day to day projects.
cons: Dealing with government sector clients narrows the projects available and sales to private companies is limited.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work in but now...
job_title: Athletic Equipment Manager in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Tallahassee isn’t the worst college town. Developing area. Decent performing sports teams overall which can add perks. Can’t think of much more honestly.
cons: Things really took a turn for the worse in the last few years. A failing football team and an indecisive, cost cutting AD has the department in disarray. Terrible pay. Far from the family atmosphere it used to be

job_title: ERP Analyst Internship in Tallahassee, FL
pros: great job with tremendous opportunity to become a great problem solver with solutions by Oracle and build your SQL shills as well. This job is demanding and fresh in the market.
cons: great job with tremendous opportunity. However, if you are not the type of student that is able to get your work done and complete the last that are handed to you. You will find yourself swamped with work on both ends. So, if you are not a student that can handle multiple issues at one this is not for you.

review_title: The university is badly mismanaged.  One of the worst universities I've experienced.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Working as a graduate student can afford you the freedom to work on something you are passionate about and to work people who are masters of their field.  The university has some interesting cultural activities like plays and concerts.
cons:
The university is extremely top heavy, with administrators making huge salaries, while those who do the actual research and education work are paid as little as possible.  Graduate students carry out most of the teaching burden rather than professors or permanent staff, lowering the quality of education for undergraduates.  In turn, graduate students are paid well below a living wage (usually between 10k and 20k per year) to do 60+ hours/week of high-skill work.  This lasts for five, six, often even seven or more years while students struggle to finish a degree amongst shifting, uncertain expectations.  The university then charges five thousand dollars a year back from paychecks for "tuition and fees", even for students who aren't taking a single actual class (as of 2010 graduate students who have finished their coursework are required to take 12 hours of "dissertation research" or other make believe filler courses so that the university can charge them tuition).  These fees are not made clear up front, and change frequently.  Graduate assistants are also required to buy their own health insurance, the same goes for supplies such as books, work computers, special software, etc.  They and often crammed in to tiny, windowless offices with a dozen other researchers, or not provided office space at all.  

Administrators are all extremely eager to sell of university services to to private companies who gut and mismanage them.  Such as signing students up and automatically depositing their financial aid in to bank accounts where they are then gouged with predatory fees. The IT for the university (such as the web infrastructure) is insultingly bad for a public university, probably because administrators contract this work out to incompetent companies à la Obamacare.  They make up for the technological dysfunction by maintaining a gigantic, ineffective bureaucracy of low level functionaries in the offices surrounding the gigantic football stadium.

pros: Good over all,  you can tap the knowledge of other colleges or departments for advice or contribute to the community. Plenty of professional groups you can join to increase your abilities within the FSU IT infrastructure.
cons: Parking is a hassle unless you land an office off campus. They also charge you a fee The bureaucracy  can be tedious at times.

pros: As a student there at the time I was unsure of how things would be run but the environment, my co-workers attitudes, & the support from my boss made it worth while.
cons: Because it is a job for the school they closely monitor your grades & that factors in whether or not you can be employed. It is pretty easy to meet the minimum but any off semester could mess up your chances.

pros: Flexible hours help to make it easy to work and to remain on top of my studies.  The leadership is incredibly helpful and understanding about issues pertaining to school.
cons: There really are no downsides to working where I do.  I understand that other areas may not be as well managed but with great leadership and flexible hours I have nothing to complain about.

job_title: Commercial Operations Manager in Tallahassee, FL

All tuition is paid for by FSU with little exceptions. Great for people looking for a full time experienced job while getting an advanced degree.
cons: Little promotion. Because this is a public entity, the amount someone can be promoted is legally limited per year. The only way to get a massive increase in pay within the same position is to acquire an additional job related degree.

pros: Working with kids always fulfilling. Management harsh at times, but only when the health and safety of the kids is in question. The director has mastered a balance between professional and friendly. Collaborative environment makes you feel like you are contributing to the program.
cons: Counselors are very young, either straight out of high school or still in college. Most were ok, but a lot of the younger ones were immature and made it difficult to watch large groups of students.

review_title: Receptionist- Great position to consider for learning important tasks
job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Tallahassee, FL
pros: The alone time, person to person communication experience, self reliance, the ability to spend time on your personal Electronic devices.
cons: Only downside is pay, which is minimum wage. But it is all worth it, the one con the job has is a pro in itself- you don’t really have to maintain or actively do much, you possess responsibility in contributing to an organization, and you get to do whatever you’d like as a distraction in between interactions.

review_title: Loved working in this this envirnoment
pros: I really enjoyed working at FSU.  I met a lot of good people during my time that became really good friends.  I also enjoyed the environment in which i worked; good working relations.  And the pay is decent, depending on what level you start at.
cons: Didn't really like the 10% raise policy that was incorporate while I was there.  Some times you can assume more job responsible and your pay grade doesn't match.

review_title: Teaching assistant at FAMU-FSU College of Engineering, ECE Department
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Good opportunities for new graduate students that are not part of a funded research group to pay for graduate school.
cons: Internal politics are slowly destroying the programs, and their reputations... Different standards for FAMU students than for FSU students, unfortunately.

review_title: Good place, challenging politics like the rest of Tallahassee
pros:
Great Office Culture
Work for a great University
Working to benefit the education and programs for the students
cons:
Politics
Leadership
Micromanagement
Employee Development
Promotions weren't always the most qualified candidate
Rules changed for favorites but not all

pros: Florida State University has for four years had the most consistently helpful and caring individuals I've encountered at any organization. The level of service and attention given to each person is astounding.
cons: Because it is a university, some of the decision making processes are out of the ordinary. It was never a problem for me, but it could be uncomfortable for some.

review_title: Great place to work, low pay
pros: Florida State University has excellent facilities and infrastructure. Benefits are adequate. The campus is beautiful and the community is nice. The professors are top notch.
cons: Most of the employees are underpaid, but the morale is high. Health insurance could be better. The work expected of us is more than we are compensated for.

review_title: Fitness Instructor at Leach - Perfect Part-Time Job for Motivated Student!
pros: Great co-worker culture, energetic team environment, great upper level staff leadership.
cons: Scheduling changes were sometimes challenging with last minute changes towards the ends of the semesters.

job_title: Collections Assistant in Pompano Beach, FL
pros: Great Benefits, Simple job for daily collection practices.  Great jump off point for career with another company.  Good place to get an understanding of what great benefits look like.
cons: Low Pay with no Room for Advancement.  Basic state job. Working against same co-workers for the same promotion.  Promises made but never kept but was most likely only within the single department for I worked within other departments within the Univeristy that created the opportunity for advancement.

pros: Great university to work for.  Employee can move up the career ladder.
cons: Working under certain supervisor can be not a productive situation.  If employee becomes sick due to an illness which takes longer than FMLA allows, an employee will have to resign, and once former employee is able to return to work.  She or he will be overlooked, even if employee was always to work on time.

pros: Nice environment, relatively good pay for graduate students, surrounded by intelligent people, university has your back when dealing with undergrads.
cons: As a graduate student, you are relatively expendable. The culture varies greatly by department, but the bureaucracy is invariant. Coming in, there's a song and dance about what a loving family the department is, but at the end of the day it's a job. After signing on the dotted line, be prepared to deal with funding issues.

pros: The faculty are great, they do a good job orienting new faculty. It is a beautiful campus.
cons: Once faculty orientation is over, it got lonely. Unfortunately, my boss loved to torture PIs and me. She says she is a 'big fish in a small pond' and she never lets anyone forget how much power she has.

pros: Flexible hours, competitive pay, free movies, free promotional materials, fantastic management and programming, relaxed environment, easy to work with school and extracurricular schedules.
cons: The occasional late night movies will leave you with getting out of work well after two in the morning. Other than this there were no real negatives to the job.

review_title: My experience was good, and I would definitely recommend it to other students as they work through school.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros: It was a very flexible position that was easy to manage with my school work. As a research assistant, I was able to pull in a stipend while doing work that would help my resume.
cons: While it was flexible with my schedule and somewhat related to my area of study, much of what I did was data entry and rather boring.

pros:
Compared to other universities and college FSU pays adjuncts well. (approx. $5000 per course in my department)
Quality Students
Fair Amount of Freedom

Most of the cons have to do with being an adjunct. No contract, no idea if classes will be available.
They limit you to 4 classes per year.
The university seems to be moving away from using adjuncts due to the bad publicity about adjuncts in higher education, and to avoid issues with the Affordable Care Act.

pros:
Work with knowledgable faculty.
Great area to live in.

pros: Supervisors understand that assistants are also students, and so they allow more flexibility in  everyone's schedule. It is also a very convenient job to have while taking classes.

pros: All around good work environment. Working at a university gives ample chance to further one's education. Not much micromanagement.  Although young, was treated as a team member and allowed to self-direct and make decisions.

pros: Great benefits if you are looking to take college courses. There are terrific medical benefits too.

pros: Fellow colleagues are an integral part. High level of education around constantly. Compensated for a job you don't mind having. Constantly around education and intelligent people, enhances workers' lives more and provides a tolerable and enjoyable place to work.

pros: Large campus with lots of diversity and creature comforts. A medium endowment also makes finding money for small start-up projects easier than at some places with less cash on hand.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tallahassee, FL

pros: The campus is nice to work in. The climate is good. The work pressure is low and you can finish your work early.

pros:

review_title: Graduate Student with Teaching Assistant Duties at Florida State University
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL

review_title: This was a very great company to work for.

review_title: Research assistant at Florida State University

review_title: Worse experience I have ever had after working for 5 educational  institutions in 3 countries
pros: The only Pros in my position was the illusions of the beginning. Other positions like full faculties and staffs are full of benefits; but they make sure that the benefits remain only for them, so that they can shimmer it to tempory positions people, and exploit them as much as possible.
cons:
A world of modern slavery for postdocs. At FSU, they have a category of employees called OPS, with no benefit, and that can be fired at anytime even for no reason. They put most of the postdocs in that category. They don't mention it in the negociation nor in the offer and they don't give any documentation for the category; at least in my case. I found it for the first time on the pay check. Then I searched for the signification but it was too late, I was already in the position as an international postdoc with no possibility to change the employer without the agreement of the current employer. And there are many international people in similar situation. I found it ridiculous for a ranked University in US, to exploit the international people that way.
- I am also impressed by the gossip: a professor always saying how bad are other people, how bad are other institutions. 
- It is the first time I found a distinguished professor spending most of his time digging into the private life of people with whom he works; investing a lot to find other people they meet, what they discuss, what they do of their free time. Inviting mutual acquaintance to dinner just to get more details. To compensate the time he spent in unuseful investigations, he overloads people with whom he works. Calling at night and during the week-end, hidding behind checking on them to give them extra work.
- I was disapointed to hear a HR agent telling me that I am an OPS employee and can be fired at any time even for no reason. I understood that the system is build like that, and that it is not helpful to report any mistreatment to the HR.

pros: I worked under the Libraries Department. The supervisors were nice and willing to work with your class schedule.
cons: It was a night gig. Dealing with people who ask the same questions over and over, when you're quite tired, can be a challenge.

job_title: Program Assistant/Administrative Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
Good Benefits
Holidays
Paid Week off at Christmas (no leave required)
cons:
no raises
no bonuses
treated like crap by supervisors when filed sexual harassment claim.

I was sexually harassed by a co-worker who worked in a different office (same department).  I filed a complaint and he was told to stay away from me.  Less than a month later, that same employee was promoted to work in my office hand and hand with me.  When I told my boss I wasn't comfortable with that, he told me to grow up and get over it.   Asked HR to help me transfer to another area as this wasn't ok, and was told i needed to find a job on my own.  for the next 2 years i was written up for no reason, treated like crap, and my boss even went as far as to call potential employers and tell them how lousy I was.  The head of the department sent multiple emails out about how sexual harassment wasn't tolerated in our department and any complaint would be handled by immediate dismissal.  When brought to his attention, he said there was nothing he could do about it.  (on a side note, the employee continued to sexually harass costumers, employees, etc.  he's been promoted twice and has even received employee of the year twice even though he has multiple offenses in his records)  

I was told by HR that if any retaliation took place to let them know as that also wasn't tolerated.  i had multiple witnesses write statements saying they heard him make comments about having me fired and she wont be there for long.  HR did nothing.  Instead i was punished and written up.  I took 3 days off for being sick, brought in the proper paperwork stating i was out due to illness and continued to work on things i missed.  I was then suspended for 3 days for "not showing up to work" and "failure to complete assignments" for the 3 days i was out.  I tried fighting it only to lose and being told by the director i was just very disgruntled.   Those witnesses who stood up for me were also punished as well.  When I filed for FMLA due to pregnancy, I was told my boss that "i GUESS its ok" (cause he has an say on my family) and later even said when i called in a double ear infection and severe bronchitis "I KNOW YOU'RE FAKING THIS PREGNANCY TO GET OUT OF WORK!" 

When i handed in my 2 weeks (which was kind in my opinion), they were shocked and i was asked if i was leaving due to supervision issues.

review_title: A great place to get a degree in physics!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tallahassee, FL
pros:
Offers a combined physics Masters/PhD program, getting your Masters on the way to the PhD.
